elements.content: The hydrogen-bonding pattern present in [Cu2(sgly)2(H2O)]·H2O [1; H2sgly = N-(2-hydroxybenzyl)glycine] has been found to be very similar to that observed in [Cu2(sala)2(H2O)] (2), which undergoes solid state transformation from a hydrogen-bonded one-dimensional helical coordination polymeric structure to a three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymeric network structure with chiral channels, after losing all of the water molecules below 110 °C. However, 1 fails to undergo such a transformation when dehydrated thermally. Furthermore, the intermolecular hydrogen bonds in 1 are weaker than those found in 2. A detailed crystal structure analysis of 1 reveals that the presence of the CO···π intermolecular interaction between a carboxylate carbonyl group and a phenyl ring appears to be responsible for the weakening of hydrogen bonds, thermal dehydration behavior, preventing the formation of new Cu−O bonds and, hence, the 3D coordination polymeric network structure.
elements.clean_text: The hydrogen-bonding pattern present in [Cu2(sgly)2(H2O)]⋅H2O [1; H2sgly = N-(2-hydroxybenzyl)glycine] has been found to be very similar to that observed in [Cu2(sala)2(H2O)] (2), which undergoes solid state transformation from a hydrogen-bonded one-dimensional helical coordination polymeric structure to a three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymeric network structure with chiral channels, after losing all of the water molecules below 110 °C. However, 1 fails to undergo such a transformation when dehydrated thermally. Furthermore, the intermolecular hydrogen bonds in 1 are weaker than those found in 2. A detailed crystal structure analysis of 1 reveals that the presence of the CO⋅⋅⋅π intermolecular interaction between a carboxylate carbonyl group and a phenyl ring appears to be responsible for the weakening of hydrogen bonds, thermal dehydration behavior, preventing the formation of new Cu-O bonds and, hence, the 3D coordination polymeric network structure.

elements.content: The hydrogen-bonding pattern present in [Cu2(sgly)2(H2O)]·H2O [1; H2sgly = N-(2-hydroxybenzyl)glycine] has been found to be very similar to that observed in [Cu2(sala)2(H2O)] (2), which undergoes solid state transformation from a hydrogen-bonded one-dimensional helical coordination polymeric structure to a three-dimensional coordination polymeric network structure with chiral channels, after losing all of the water molecules below 110 °C.
elements.clean_text: The hydrogen-bonding pattern present in [Cu2(sgly)2(H2O)]⋅H2O [1; H2sgly = N-(2-hydroxybenzyl)glycine] has been found to be very similar to that observed in [Cu2(sala)2(H2O)] (2), which undergoes solid state transformation from a hydrogen-bonded one-dimensional helical coordination polymeric structure to a three-dimensional coordination polymeric network structure with chiral channels, after losing all of the water molecules below 110 °C.

elements.content:
Delivered at the International Conference on Materials for Advanced Technologies 2003, Singapore, December 7−12, 2003.

Weak noncovalent interactions play an important role in the packing of molecules in the solid state and hence their physical properties and chemical reactivities. Of these, the relative orientations of the reactive functional groups can control the solid state reactivities and alter the stabilities of the crystal structures. In this communication, we report the influence of the CO···π interaction on the hydrogen bonding, the solid state supramolecular transformation, and the thermal dehydration behavior of [Cu2(sgly)2(H2O)]·H2O [1; H2sgly = N-(2-hydroxybenzyl)glycine, shown below].
elements.clean_text:
Delivered at the International Conference on Materials for Advanced Technologies 2003, Singapore, December 7-12, 2003.



Weak noncovalent interactions play an important role in the packing of molecules in the solid state and hence their physical properties and chemical reactivities. Of these, the relative orientations of the reactive functional groups can control the solid state reactivities and alter the stabilities of the crystal structures. In this communication, we report the influence of the CO⋅⋅⋅π interaction on the hydrogen bonding, the solid state supramolecular transformation, and the thermal dehydration behavior of [Cu2(sgly)2(H2O)]⋅H2O [1; H2sgly = N-(2-hydroxybenzyl)glycine, shown below].

elements.content: Sometime ago, a honeycomb-like hydrogen-bonded three-dimensional (3D) network structure in [Zn2(sala)2(H2O)2]·2H2O [H2sala = N-(2-hydroxybenzyl)-l-alanine] was found to transform into another 3D coordination polymeric compound, [Zn2(sala)2], irreversibly on thermal dehydration below 110°. Such a supramolecular structural transformation has been made interconvertible by substituting the backbone of the ligand by suitable nonreactive functional groups. A Cu(II) complex with a hydrogen-bonded one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymeric structure was also found to lose a coordinated water molecule on thermal dehydration to form a 3D network structure similar to the Zn(II) analogue. The presence of complementary N−H···O hydrogen bonds has been found to assist these transformations.
elements.clean_text: Sometime ago, a honeycomb-like hydrogen-bonded three-dimensional (3D) network structure in [Zn2(sala)2(H2O)2]⋅2H2O [H2sala = N-(2-hydroxybenzyl)-l-alanine] was found to transform into another 3D coordination polymeric compound, [Zn2(sala)2], irreversibly on thermal dehydration below 110°. Such a supramolecular structural transformation has been made interconvertible by substituting the backbone of the ligand by suitable nonreactive functional groups. A Cu(II) complex with a hydrogen-bonded one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymeric structure was also found to lose a coordinated water molecule on thermal dehydration to form a 3D network structure similar to the Zn(II) analogue. The presence of complementary N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds has been found to assist these transformations.

elements.content: The crystal structure of 1, reported in 1989 by Xu and co-workers and determined independently by us, has been found to be very close to that of 2. To understand and rationalize the intermolecular interactions favoring structural transformation in the solid state, we have analyzed the intermolecular interactions present in 1 in detail and investigated their thermal dehydration properties. The Cu(II) complex 1 crystallizes as a 1D helical coordination polymer built up of dimeric building blocks similar to 2 as shown in Figure . The major difference between 1 and 2 is the presence of one more water molecule in the lattice. This oxygen atom, O(8) of the lattice water molecule, is involved in a weak intramolecular C−H···O hydrogen bonding to the methylene hydrogen of the amino acid moiety [C18−H18b···O8 (1/2 + x, 1/2 − y, −z)]. Furthermore, one of the hydrogen atoms of this lattice water is strongly hydrogen bonded to O2 as shown in Figure a.
elements.clean_text: The crystal structure of 1, reported in 1989 by Xu and co-workers and determined independently by us, has been found to be very close to that of 2. To understand and rationalize the intermolecular interactions favoring structural transformation in the solid state, we have analyzed the intermolecular interactions present in 1 in detail and investigated their thermal dehydration properties. The Cu(II) complex 1 crystallizes as a 1D helical coordination polymer built up of dimeric building blocks similar to 2 as shown in Figure . The major difference between 1 and 2 is the presence of one more water molecule in the lattice. This oxygen atom, O(8) of the lattice water molecule, is involved in a weak intramolecular C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding to the methylene hydrogen of the amino acid moiety [C18-H18b⋅⋅⋅O8 (1/2 + x, 1/2 - y, -z)]. Furthermore, one of the hydrogen atoms of this lattice water is strongly hydrogen bonded to O2 as shown in Figure a.

elements.content: (a) ORTEP diagram of1 showing the numbering scheme and hydrogen-bonding interactions with the neighboring dimers. (b) A view of a portion of the helical coordination polymer along the a-axis. The C−H hydrogens are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) ORTEP diagram of1 showing the numbering scheme and hydrogen-bonding interactions with the neighboring dimers. (b) A view of a portion of the helical coordination polymer along the a-axis. The C-H hydrogens are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The relative orientations of the neighboring helical strands are congenial for the formation of a new Cu−O3a bond upon removal of the aqua ligand attached to Cu1 by thermal dehydration. Hence, 1 is expected to undergo topochemical thermal conversion similar to 2 to give a 3D coordination polymeric network structure. However, our attempts to isolate the anhydrous complex were unsuccessful. Further investigations revealed that the anhydrous solid is not stable in air and rehydrated to form 1 reversibly. Thermogravimetric analysis of the fresh sample of 1 shows a weight loss of 6.7% in the temperature range of 50−190 °C, corresponding to the loss of about two water molecules (Figure ). The DTG indicates a two-step thermal dehydration pattern; the first step corresponds to the removal of the lattice water molecule, and the second step corresponds to the elimination of the aqua ligand. This pattern is quite different from that of [Zn2(Sala)2(H2O)2]·2H2O, which shows only a one-step thermal dehydration pattern below 110 °C for the removal of both coordinated and lattice water molecules.
elements.clean_text: The relative orientations of the neighboring helical strands are congenial for the formation of a new Cu-O3a bond upon removal of the aqua ligand attached to Cu1 by thermal dehydration. Hence, 1 is expected to undergo topochemical thermal conversion similar to 2 to give a 3D coordination polymeric network structure. However, our attempts to isolate the anhydrous complex were unsuccessful. Further investigations revealed that the anhydrous solid is not stable in air and rehydrated to form 1 reversibly. Thermogravimetric analysis of the fresh sample of 1 shows a weight loss of 6.7% in the temperature range of 50-190 °C, corresponding to the loss of about two water molecules (Figure ). The DTG indicates a two-step thermal dehydration pattern; the first step corresponds to the removal of the lattice water molecule, and the second step corresponds to the elimination of the aqua ligand. This pattern is quite different from that of [Zn2(Sala)2(H2O)2]⋅2H2O, which shows only a one-step thermal dehydration pattern below 110 °C for the removal of both coordinated and lattice water molecules.

elements.content: TG and DTG curve showing the dehydration of1.
elements.clean_text: 2  TG and DTG curve showing the dehydration of1.

elements.content: The solid state structures of 1 [cell data:  a = 7.348(2) Å, b = 11.388(2) Å, and c = 24.295(5) Å]7,9 and 2 [cell data:  a = 7.3850(2) Å, b = 10.0669(2) Å, c = 28.6676(8) Å]6 are roughly isomorphous and but not isostructural. Except for the methyl substituent on the amino acid side chain, the conformation of the dimeric building block in 1 is expected to be similar to that in 2. However, it is found that the phenyl ring, C8, and C18 in the two structures are not exactly superimposed (Supporting Information). In the crystal structure of 1, the helical strands are arranged parallel to the a-axis and are further hydrogen bonded to one another in the bc plane to give a honeycomb-like network structure similar to 2. The carbonyl oxygen atom, O3, of the ligand is hydrogen bonded to two hydrogen atoms, N−H and O−H, as shown in Figure . Detailed analysis of the crystal packing revealed that the significant differences between these two complexes originate from the interlinkage of the helical strands. The relative orientations of the neighboring dimers interacting through hydrogen bonds in 1 and 2 are shown in Figure . It is obvious that the packing of the helical polymers is affected by the methyl groups.
elements.clean_text: The solid state structures of 1 [cell data: a = 7.348(2) Å, b = 11.388(2) Å, and c = 24.295(5) Å]7,9 and 2 [cell data: a = 7.3850(2) Å, b = 10.0669(2) Å, c = 28.6676(8) Å]6 are roughly isomorphous and but not isostructural. Except for the methyl substituent on the amino acid side chain, the conformation of the dimeric building block in 1 is expected to be similar to that in 2. However, it is found that the phenyl ring, C8, and C18 in the two structures are not exactly superimposed (Supporting Information). In the crystal structure of 1, the helical strands are arranged parallel to the a-axis and are further hydrogen bonded to one another in the bc plane to give a honeycomb-like network structure similar to 2. The carbonyl oxygen atom, O3, of the ligand is hydrogen bonded to two hydrogen atoms, N-H and O-H, as shown in Figure . Detailed analysis of the crystal packing revealed that the significant  differences between these two complexes originate from the interlinkage of the helical strands. The relative orientations of the neighboring dimers interacting through hydrogen bonds in 1 and 2 are shown in Figure . It is obvious that the packing of the helical polymers is affected by the methyl groups.

elements.content: Perspective views of the hydrogen bond contacts in1 (left) and 2 (right), respectively.
elements.clean_text: 3  Perspective views of the hydrogen bond contacts in1 (left) and 2 (right), respectively.

elements.content: The Cu1···Cu2 distances are 2.973 Å in 1 and 2.950 Å in 2. The O3A···Cu1 distance, 3.912 Å in 1, is significantly longer than 3.698 Å in 2. The hydrogen bond parameters in 1 are also considerably weaker. A comparison of hydrogen bond parameters indicates that H1···O3A, 2.42 Å, and H4A···O3A, 2.28 Å, in 1 are longer than the corresponding distances in 2 (H1···O3A, 2.00 Å; H4A···O3A, 2.10 Å). Furthermore, the plane containing the carboxylate group of the neighboring dimers, namely, C8A, C9A, O2A, and O3A, is more parallel to the phenyl ring in 1 (the interplanar angle, 8.9°) than in 2 (the interplanar angle, 26°) due to the absence of sterically bulky methyl groups as shown in Figure .
elements.clean_text: The Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu2 distances are 2.973 Å in 1 and 2.950 Å in 2. The O3A⋅⋅⋅Cu1 distance, 3.912 Å in 1, is significantly longer than 3.698 Å in 2. The hydrogen bond parameters in 1 are also considerably weaker. A comparison of hydrogen bond parameters indicates that H1⋅⋅⋅O3A, 2.42 Å, and H4A⋅⋅⋅O3A, 2.28 Å, in 1 are longer than the corresponding distances in 2 (H1⋅⋅⋅O3A, 2.00 Å; H4A⋅⋅⋅O3A, 2.10 Å). Furthermore, the plane containing the carboxylate group of the neighboring dimers, namely, C8A, C9A, O2A, and O3A, is more parallel to the phenyl ring in 1 (the interplanar angle, 8.9°) than in 2 (the interplanar angle, 26°) due to the absence of sterically bulky methyl groups as shown in Figure .

elements.content: Top views of the interactions between the carboxyl group and the phenyl ring in1 and 2.
elements.clean_text: 4  Top views of the interactions between the carboxyl group and the phenyl ring in1 and 2.

elements.content: A close examination of the interactions between the carboxylate group and the phenyl ring edge in 1 reveals that they are aligned almost parallel and separated by 3.352 Å (C9A···C5) in 1 and 3.650 Å (C9A···C5) in 2. This CO···π interaction between these two groups in 1 is shown pictorially in Figure . Although similar interactions between the carboxylate carbonyl group and the phenyl ring have been observed before, this was documented by Addadi and Lahav for the first time in 1979. Later, Moorthy et al. interpreted the solid state photochemical reactivity of some coumarin derivatives in terms of CO···π interactions. However, this interaction has not been exploited as a routine tool in the design and construction of supramolecular structures.
elements.clean_text: A close examination of the interactions between the carboxylate group and the phenyl ring edge in 1 reveals that they are aligned almost parallel and separated by 3.352 Å (C9A⋅⋅⋅C5) in 1 and 3.650 Å (C9A⋅⋅⋅C5) in 2. This CO⋅⋅⋅π interaction between these two groups in 1 is shown pictorially in Figure . Although similar interactions between the carboxylate carbonyl group and the phenyl ring have been observed before, this was documented by Addadi and Lahav for the first time in 1979. Later, Moorthy et al. interpreted the solid state photochemical reactivity of some coumarin derivatives in terms of CO⋅⋅⋅π interactions. However, this interaction has not been exploited as a routine tool in the design and construction of supramolecular structures.

elements.content: CO···π interaction between the carboxylate CO group and the phenyl ring in 1.
elements.clean_text: 5  CO⋅⋅⋅π interaction between the carboxylate CO group and the phenyl ring in 1.

elements.content: The CO···π attractive interaction in 1 appears to hold back the carboxylate group from coming closer to the aqua ligands and NH protons as revealed by the weaker hydrogen bond parameters. A comparison of similar hydrogen bond parameters in 2 will support this fact. Furthermore, this CO···π interaction tends to prevent the formation of a new Cu−O bond upon thermal dehydration despite the presence of hydrogen bonds and disposition of the reactive groups congenial for topochemical reactions to occur in the solid state. Surprisingly, this weak CO···π interaction appears to be responsible for the loss of the coordinated water molecule to take place at elevated temperature unlike 2. On the other hand, such an interaction is absent in 2 and thus accounts for the observation of topochemical transformation.
elements.clean_text: The CO⋅⋅⋅π attractive interaction in 1 appears to hold back the carboxylate group from coming closer to the aqua ligands and NH protons as revealed by the weaker hydrogen bond parameters. A comparison of similar hydrogen bond parameters in 2 will support this fact. Furthermore, this CO⋅⋅⋅π interaction tends to prevent the formation of a new Cu-O bond upon thermal dehydration despite the presence of hydrogen bonds and disposition of the reactive groups congenial for topochemical reactions to occur in the solid state. Surprisingly, this weak CO⋅⋅⋅π interaction appears to be responsible for the loss of the coordinated water molecule to take place at elevated temperature unlike 2. On the other hand, such an interaction is absent in 2 and thus accounts for the observation of topochemical transformation.

elements.content: In summary, the hydrogen-bonded packing in the solid state structure of 1 has been found to be very similar to that of 2, which is favorable for solid state supramolecular transformation. Detailed experimental studies and the analysis of crystal packing revealed that this compound does not exhibit this property. Subtle structural differences in 1 have been attributed to the presence of a CO···π interaction between the adjacent phenyl ring and the carboxylate group. The impact of weak interactions such as CO···π on the solid state thermal dehydration properties observed here appears to be unprecedented. Although the CO···π interaction has been noted as early as 1979, and later discussed in connection with structure−reactivity correlations of the photochemical behavior of coumarin derivatives, surprisingly, it has not been exploited as a routine tool to design and construct multidimensional architectures in crystal engineering and to control the solid state reactivity. Here, the weak interaction responsible for the difference in the solid state property is circumstantial, and its influence on the solid state structures and hence its property may not have been substantiated without similar studies with 2.
elements.clean_text: In summary, the hydrogen-bonded packing in the solid state structure of 1 has been found to be very similar to  that of 2, which is favorable for solid state supramolecular transformation. Detailed experimental studies and the analysis of crystal packing revealed that this compound does not exhibit this property. Subtle structural differences in 1 have been attributed to the presence of a CO⋅⋅⋅π interaction between the adjacent phenyl ring and the carboxylate group. The impact of weak interactions such as CO⋅⋅⋅π on the solid state thermal dehydration properties observed here appears to be unprecedented. Although the CO⋅⋅⋅π interaction has been noted as early as 1979, and later discussed in connection with structure-reactivity correlations of the photochemical behavior of coumarin derivatives, surprisingly, it has not been exploited as a routine tool to design and construct multidimensional architectures in crystal engineering and to control the solid state reactivity. Here, the weak interaction responsible for the difference in the solid state property is circumstantial, and its influence on the solid state structures and hence its property may not have been substantiated without similar studies with 2.

elements.content: Figures highlighting the differences between the structures of 1 and 2, TG and DTG diagrams, hydrogen bond tables, and X-ray crystallographic information files for 1. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

However, our attempts to isolate the anhydrous complex were unsuccessful. Further investigations revealed that the anhydrous solid is not stable in air and rehydrated to form 1 reversibly. Thermogravimetric analysis of the fresh sample of 1 shows a weight loss of 6.7% in the temperature range of 50−190 °C, corresponding to the loss of about two water molecules (Figure ). This pattern is quite different from that of [Zn2(Sala)2(H2O)2]·2H2O, which shows only a one-step thermal dehydration pattern below 110 °C for the removal of both coordinated and lattice water molecules.

metadata.title:
Influence of the CO···π Interaction on the Thermal Dehydration
Behavior of [Cu2(sgly)2(H2O)]·1H2O
†
